thread.title: Step inside WestJet's new Frozen-themed plane [Video]
thread.title_full: Step inside WestJet's new Frozen-themed plane [Video]

title: Step inside WestJet's new Frozen-themed plane [Video]
text:
Airports, Airlines & Security 
WestJet's second-ever Disney-themed plane isn't just cool, it's Frozen. 
The aircraft, unveiled in Toronto last Sunday , is a tribute to the highest-grossing animated film of all time. 
The plane's tail features film characters Anna and Elsa celebrating winter. The scene warms up toward the nose of the airplane, where lovable snowman Olaf can be seen basking on a beach -- perhaps one of the 100 destinations WestJet offers scheduled service to. 
The plane's interior is also Frozen-themed with different designs on headrests and overhead bins. 
The Frozen-themed aircraft will join WestJet's "Magic Plane," which features Sorcerer Mickey. 
"Two years ago, we launched the Magic Plane, our first Disney-themed aircraft, and no matter where it flies throughout our network, it is the most-anticipated and most-photographed aircraft in WestJet history," Bob Cummings, an executive vice-president with the airline, said. "Today, we are proud to team up with our great friends at Disney to create a sequel like no other." 
The Frozen-themed aircraft will fly to Orlando, the closes airport to the Walt Disney World Resort, and all of WestJet's other 737-jet routes. 
FAST FACTS ON #DISNEYFROZENTHEMEDPLANE 
-- The aircraft was painted in Fort Worth, Tx. 
-- It took 21 days to complete the paint job, with a constant crew of six painters working 12-hour rotations around the clock. 
-- Some 643.5 litres of paint in 23 different colours were used. 
-- To create the full Frozen effect, sparkles were added to the paint to add shimmer when the plane is in motion. Step inside WestJet's new Frozen-themed plane By Irene Thomaidis , Toronto Sun First posted: Sunday, October 25, 2015 12:00 AM MDT WestJet's second-ever Disney-themed plane isn't just cool, it's Frozen. Also in this article A 'Frozen' Plane Proves Disney Is Never Letting It Go Top stories
